pages.text: I remember the awe I felt in my first days as an apprentice at the Eternal University. The soaring, gold-domed towers, perpetual twilit sky abuzz with luminous wisps, the impossibly large spaces contained within far too small buildings.$(br2)All of that wonder came crashing down as soon as I attended my first lesson. The master stood above us

speaking from a dark wooden podium with golden accents, bellowing to us about responsibility, diligence, and the importance of authority.$(br2)His words drained all the wonder from the place. Some of my peers left the University after the speech. Some disregarded his words and were lost. Most, (including myself, to my shame), paid heed to his words and became diligent little cogs in the great research machine.

I know not if he used sorcery to emphasize his lesson to us, or if he was simply an old, self-important blowhard. I often find myself wondering about it when my mind is otherwise unoccupied.$(br2)A few years back, the Magistocracy ordered a curriculum review. It was decided that the method of teaching be changed from a master speaking to a great collection of students to a single master and apprentice,

eliminating the need for those damned podia. I took one back with me to my Sanctum, and I take great pleasure in consigning it to the fate of a writing desk in some forgotten corner.$(br2)A good riddance, I say. To the podia, the old masters, and everything their close-minded reign at the University brought forth.
